title: 108_s2237
content: The Act titled "Protecting Intellectual Rights Against Theft and Expropriation Act of 2004" authorizes civil copyright enforcement by the Attorney General. The "Protecting Intellectual Rights Against Theft and Expropriation Act of 2004" allows the Attorney General to pursue civil penalties for copyright violations under section 506. The civil action can be taken in the appropriate US district court, with penalties equal to those awarded under title 18. Other remedies are not precluded by the imposition of civil penalties. The "Protecting Intellectual Rights Against Theft and Expropriation Act of 2004" allows the Attorney General to pursue civil penalties for copyright violations under section 506. Restitution received in a civil action can be offset against damages in a subsequent copyright infringement case. Amendments to Section 504 of title 17, United States Code, include allowing the Attorney General to bring a civil action and removing gender-specific language. Amendments to Section 504 of title 17, United States Code, allow the Attorney General to bring a civil action for copyright violations and remove gender-specific language. The table of sections for chapter 5 of title 17 is updated to reflect these changes. SEC. 3. Authorization of funding for training and pilot program. The Attorney General must develop a training program within 180 days of this Act for effective civil enforcement of copyright laws, including educating personnel on intellectual property, legal frameworks, and challenges in protecting digital copyrighted works from online piracy. The Attorney General's training program includes guidance on copyright enforcement actions, strategic issues, technical expertise in computer forensics, data collection for court proceedings, victim copyright owner's role in enforcement actions and damages computation. The Attorney General's training program covers guidance on copyright enforcement actions, strategic issues, computer forensics expertise, court proceedings data collection, victim copyright owner's role in enforcement actions, damages computation, injunctions, impoundment, forfeiture, civil enforcement authority implementation pilot program, and annual reporting to Congress on enforcement progress and training programs. The annual report for the Department of Justice includes details on civil actions filed under section 506a of title 17, United States Code, such as the number of investigative matters, defendants involved, actions filed, actions resolved, defendants in those actions, and the disposition of those actions. The annual report for the Department of Justice includes details on civil actions filed under section 506a of title 17, United States Code, including the number of cases, outcomes (settled, dismissed, or resolved after trial), civil penalties imposed, amount remitted to copyright owners, training program description, personnel participation, and locations of participating US Attorneys Offices. $2,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2005 for this purpose. The Senate passed the bill on June 25, 2004. Attest: EMILY J. REYNOLDS, Secretary.
